newsitem.title: USA: Sybase sees sequential sales rise in Q2.
newsitem.headline: Sybase sees sequential sales rise in Q2.

text.p: Sybase Inc Chief Executive Mitchell Kertzman said Thursday he expects revenue in the second quarter to rise over the first quarter, but "nothing dramatic."
The developer of database software also expects see the benefit of an aggressive marketing campaign in the second half of the year, Kurtzman said in an interview.
"We're right on track for the turnaround," he said.

After the market closed, Sybase reported a better than expected first-quarter net income of $3.54 million, or $0.05 a share, compared with a loss of $6.91 million, or $0.09 a share, in the year-ago quarter.
First-quarter revenue fell slightly to $241.9 million from $243.7 million.

In the past two years, Sybase has been struggling to recover from technology and marketing missteps. To get its momentum going again, the company laid off workers last summer and unveiled an aggressive marketing campaign.

"We have the wind at our back now," Kertzman said. "We'll look for sequential revenue growth in the second quarter, but I wouldn't be too rash and make a prediction about a dramatic improvement this quarter."

Sybase is planning to introduce a host of new products later this year. Kertzman said substantial revenue growth from these products and the current marketing campaign will not kick in until the third and fourth quarters.
Sybase, based in Emeryville, Calif., writes database software, the type of computer program big companies use to store and retrieve huge amounts of vital information.
